doc.previous: In 1983 the Antarctic Treaty Parties began negotiations on a convention to regulate mining in Antarctica 75 A coalition of international organizations 76 launched a public pressure campaign to prevent any minerals development in the region led largely by Greenpeace International 77 which established its own scientific station World Park Base in the Ross Sea region 78 and conducted annual expeditions to document environmental effects of humans on Antarctica 79 In 1988 the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resources CRAMRA was adopted 80 The following year however Australia and France announced that they would not ratify the convention rendering it dead for all intents and purposes They proposed instead that a comprehensive regime to protect the Antarctic environment be negotiated in its place 81 The Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty the Madrid Protocol was negotiated as other countries followed suit and on 14 January 1998 it entered into force 81 82 The Madrid Protocol bans all mining in Antarctica designating Antarctica a natural reserve devoted to peace and science
doc.after: The Antarctic Treaty prohibits any military activity in Antarctica including the establishment of military bases and fortifications military manoeuvers and weapons testing Military personnel or equipment are permitted only for scientific research or other peaceful purposes 83 The only documented military land manoeuvre was Operation NINETY by the Argentine military 84
